profileText: A Senator from Wisconsin; born in Fond du Lac, Fond du Lac County, Wis., April 25, 1866; moved with his parents to Mayville, Wis., in 1876; attended the public schools and the law school of the University of Wisconsin at Madison; admitted to the bar in 1895 and commenced practice in Mayville, Wis.; district attorney of Dodge County 1902-1906; member, State senate 1907-1913; elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate in 1914 and served from March 4, 1915, until his accidental death while duck hunting on Rush Lake, near Picketts, Wis., on October 21, 1917; chairman, Committee to Investigate Trespassers Upon Indian Land (Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth Congresses), Committee on Fisheries (Sixty-fifth Congress); interment in Graceland Cemetery, Mayville, Wis.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: U.S. Congress. Paul O. Husting (Late a Senator from Wisconsin). Memorial Addresses, Delivered in the Senate and the House of Representatives of the United States. 65th Cong., 3d sess., 1918-1919. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1919.

researchRecord.name: 1909-1918 (bulk 1915-1917). 32 boxes. Correspondence, letterbooks (1914-1917); campaign records (1914); Wisconsin post office patronage files; Wisconsin waterpowers and conservation files, drafts of bills; forestry and drainage files; speeches, newspaper articles and letters to editors; newspaper clippings, and scrapbooks. Strengths include documentation of patronage system for appointments to federal offices, and the attitudes of the German-language press and Wisconsin German-Americans towards the Wilson administration and the question of American participation in World War I. Other topics include preparedness, Democratic state politics, and prohibition. Finding aid.
